awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraints From Fault Roughness on the Scale-dependent Strength of Rocks
awd_abstract_narration:
The strength of crustal rocks is a fundamental factor in tectonic processes: fault motion, mountain building and crustal evolution all affect and are affected by rock strength. Despite its central importance, crustal rock strength is difficult to measure at field scales. Laboratory experiments constrain strength at sub-meter scales, but those results imply that strength is scale-dependent: large rocks are weaker than small ones. This problem is particularly serious in fault zones. Understanding of fault strength is largely based on laboratory experiments. Extending these well-controlled laboratory experimental results to natural faults is one of the major problems of fault and rock mechanics. This project explores a new approach based on the idea that fault surface roughness provides strength estimates at a wide range of scales. The study involves laboratory measurements at very small scales combined with computer modeling and direct observations of fault surfaces. Result will provide a quantitative understanding of fault friction that can be used to predict fault friction for the range of scales and geometries found in the Earth, information essential for the improved understanding of earthquake mechanics. Additional desired societal outcomes of the project include development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through graduate student post-doctoral fellow training.

There is an intimate link between fault surface roughness and strength. The yielding of asperities controls surface friction by dynamically adjusting the real area of contact in response to a load. This yielding process can control the topography on the fault surface. This project uses the observed, preserved roughness to infer the yield criteria. Since roughness occurs on multiple scales on faults, the strength (failure criterion) at a variety of scales can be inferred. The goal of this research is to make the link between fault roughness and bulk material strength properties. The first step in investigating the proposed connection between fault roughness and material strength is to measure strength directly on fault surface samples that have the observed roughness relationship. In particular, the researchers aim to understand the scale dependence of both brittle and plastic strength, and to understand the expected transition from brittle to plastic deformation with decreasing length scale. To accomplish these goals, they will use a combination of indentation and nanopillar experiments on natural fault samples to obtain a robust set of strength measurements. These results will be compared to roughness at comparable scales using Atomic Force Microscopy to measure roughness on the same samples. The next step is to establish the relevant modes of failure at various scales on natural surfaces by: (a) predict the dominant failure mode at relevant scales using the laboratory values; (b) use the observation of the minimum scale of grooving to isolate the process that separates failure modes; and (c) investigate smaller scales where the failure mode is determined by the absolute strength of the material. The research team will explore the implications of the measurements for friction by simulating the elastoplastic deformation of a rough fault using the hardness values as measured on the samples and then use the brittle failure criterion inferred from the nanopillar experiments to calculate the shear stress required for motion of the deformed surface and compare the results to typical values of fault friction.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This project tested an overarching hypothesis that the surface roughness of natural faults in the earth is determined by the strength of the rocks that are in contact on a fault surface.  When sliding occurs along natural faults, the rocks bounding the fault, particularly at relatively larger length scales, can fail in a brittle manner, with the fracture strength determined by a material property called fracture toughness, which can be described as the resistance of the material to fracture.  At smaller scales, we hypothesize that the strength of micrometer-sized bumps in contact on faults in the earth is determined by a material property called the yield strength, which is the stress at which the material fails plastically instead of in a brittle manner. The brittle or plastic failure of rocks and minerals on fault surfaces determines the roughness of the fault (basically the topography of the fault surface), which has a primary control on the strength of faults and ultimately the nucleation of earthquakes. 

A widely observed phenomenon in laboratory studies of material failure is that as the size of a test sample becomes smaller, the brittle or plastic strength of the material increases.  This “smaller is stronger” phenomenon is due to the density of crystal defects in the material - small cracks (“flaws”) in a material that limit its fracture strength, and linear defects called dislocations that limit its yield strength.  As the sample size decreases, the number of defects within the sample volume decreases, and the strength of the material increases.  In a classic demonstration of this effect, test samples that are drawn down to the size of a whisker then pulled in tension can reach their theoretical material strength (which is orders of magnitude higher than typical failure strengths) because there are no defects present to allow them to fail at a lower stress.   

To study this “smaller is stronger” phenomenon in minerals common to the interior of the earth, including in faults, we used a nanoindentation apparatus in our lab, an instrument more commonly associated with the study of engineering materials.  In these tests, a diamond indenter tip tens-of-microns in size is pressed into the surface of minerals, which causes plastic deformation of the sample.  We measured a quantity called the hardness of the material (a measure of its resistance to plastic deformation), which is proportional to the yield strength of a material.  The hardness is simply the force applied to the indenter tip divided by the area of the indent that the diamond makes in the sample.  We varied the size of the indents by varying the load on the indenter tip and observed that as the size of the indents decreased, the hardness increased, verifying the “smaller is stronger” effect for plastic deformation of minerals.  In fact, we discovered that every one of the ~25 different minerals we have ever conducted indentation tests on displays a size-dependent hardness.  In the materials science literature, the increase in hardness with decreasing size is termed the indentation size effect (ISE).

Similarly, we attempted to verify a size-dependent strength for brittle fracture using the nanoindenter.  In this case, the size of cracks that emanate from the corners of plastic indents can be used to estimate the fracture toughness of samples.  The results of these tests were inconclusive, as the use of nanoindentation tests to determine fracture toughness is fraught with uncertainty.  We also attempted to fabricate “micropillars”, small columnar structures on the surface of minerals formed by milling the sample with an ion beam, that can be deformed to failure in the nanoindenter to determine fracture toughness.  Unfortunately, we found fabrication of nanopillars to be too costly in terms of time and instrument fees.

The other major part of this project was measuring the surface roughness of real fault surfaces down to the smallest possible scales using the atomic force microscope.  We showed that down to the scale of nanometers, the aspect ratio (the height divided by the width) of asperities on the fault surface increased with decreasing size of an asperity, due to the increase in strength with decreasing size.  Nanoindentation tests on these same fault surfaces showed the indentation size effect that other mineral samples have.

Finally, in the last year of this grant, with permission from the Program Manager, we conducted experiments with a new nanoindenter that is able to indent samples as described above but also to simultaneously translate the tip across the sample surface to measure friction.  The tests let us explore the deformation occurring at single asperities in contact on a fault surface in unprecedented detail, as described in a recent paper.

This project resulted in one Phd thesis (Chris Thom’s) and 4 peer-reviewed papers.
